title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenues. The number of businesses owned by them grew by 84 percent from 1992 to 1997, with gross receipts increasing by 179 percent during that period, outpacing the growth of all businesses in the same timeframe. The Small Business Development Center program is cost-effective, with clients generating additional tax revenues of $468 million in 1998, six times the program's cost to the Federal Government. Business counseling and technical assistance are crucial on Indian lands where such services are scarce and expensive. The Small Business Development Center program provides critical business counseling and technical assistance to tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians, leading to higher survival rates for businesses on Indian lands. The Act aims to stimulate economies, foster economic development, create new small businesses, and provide management assistance to indigenous-owned businesses. Local Tribal Councils are consulted for advice on program implementation. The Act aims to provide management, technical, and research assistance to small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. It also seeks advice from local Tribal Councils on where small business development assistance is most needed and ensures full access to existing business counseling and technical assistance programs. The Act aims to provide small business development assistance to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Small Business Act is amended to provide an additional grant for Small Business Development Centers in eligible States to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians with business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Eligible States must have a population of these groups comprising at least 1 percent of the total population. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for Small Business Development Centers in eligible States with a population of Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians comprising at least 1 percent of the total population. Grant applicants must submit information on their goals, objectives, and capability to provide services to these groups. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for Small Business Development Centers in eligible States with a population of Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must demonstrate their ability to provide training and services to these groups, specify the location of the proposed center, the required grant funding, and consultation with local Tribal Councils. Applicants must comply with all requirements except for matching funds, with a maximum grant amount of $300,000. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for Small Business Development Centers in eligible States with a population of Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must comply with all requirements except for matching funds, with a maximum grant amount of $300,000. The Administration will issue final regulations for the standards of services provided by the Centers. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for Small Business Development Centers in eligible States with a population of Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Regulations will establish standards for educational, technical, and support services provided by the Centers, as well as work plan requirements. Definitions for "Indian lands" are provided in the section. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group of Indians in the contiguous United States, including the Metlakatla Indian Community. An 'Indian tribe member' is an individual recognized as eligible for services provided to Indians by the Secretary of the Interior. The Indian Community consists of members eligible for services provided to Indians by the Secretary of the Interior. The terms 'Indian tribe member,' 'Alaska Native,' and 'Native Hawaiian' are defined within specific parameters. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to a U.S. citizen who is a descendant of the aboriginal people who exercised sovereignty in Hawaii before 1778. Funding of $7,000,000 is authorized annually for fiscal years 2006-2008 for this purpose. Funding of $7,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2006-2008 is authorized for Native Hawaiian programs, with specific limitations on the use of funds. Section 21(c) of the Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers receiving grants to consult with tribal organizations on providing assistance to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.
